La defensa pide su absolución
El acusado por el crimen de la CAM evita la última palabra en el juicio
06 Nov 2019, 20:15 by La Información

Miguel López ha evitado acogerse a su derecho a la última palabra. Su defensa ha pedido su absolución por falta de pruebas "directas"

El yerno y único acusado del crimen a tiros de la viuda del expresidente de Caja Mediterráneo (CAM) Vicente Sala, Miguel López, ha evitado acogerse a su derecho a la última palabra al término del juicio en el que su defensa ha pedido su absolución por falta de pruebas "directas". Los miembros del jurado han sido citados este jueves a las 11 horas para recibir de la magistrada que preside el juicio, Francisca Bru, las preguntas que formarán parte del 'objeto del veredicto' para, en un plazo de 48 horas prorrogable dos veces, determinar si López es culpable o no culpable.
Habrá culpabilidad con posibilidad de hasta 24 años de cárcel si así lo deciden, al menos, siete de los nueve miembros del jurado y quedará exonerado de cargos si cuenta con cinco votos, según la Ley del Jurado. "Nada, muchas gracias", ha contestado López al ser preguntado por la magistrada si quería hacer uso de su derecho a la última palabra antes del veredicto, por lo que el único acusado ha terminado el juicio sin hacer declaración alguna, ni siquiera a su abogado, Javier Sánchez-Vera.
Esto ha ocurrido al término de una maratoniana sesión de casi ocho horas en la que las acusaciones de la fiscalía y la particular y su defensa han presentado sus conclusiones finales en la decimoséptima y última sesión ante las seis mujeres y tres hombres del jurado popular de la Audiencia Provincial de Alicante.



Previamente y durante dos horas y media, su letrado ha tratado de desmontar las tesis de las acusaciones, con el argumento de que no hay pruebas directas ni siquiera indicios contra su defendido sino que en las últimas semanas se ha demostrado una investigación policial "equivocada". Sánchez-Vera ha afirmado que "cuando equivocas la investigación desde el principio no puede salir nada bien" y ha añadido que su defendido, Miguel López, era "de los que mejor se llevaba con María del Carmen (Martínez), aunque se diga lo contrario".
Ha insistido en que la investigación policial no ha sido "correcta" porque ha "sustituido la prueba científica por suposiciones", lo que conduce a "errores judiciales clarísimos" en caso de que su defendido resultara considerado culpable.
Durante el juicio se ha reflejado las disputas familiares por el control de las empresas, valoradas en unos 120 millones de euros, que se traducían en dos bandos, uno formado por la víctima y su hijo primogénito (y acusación particular), Vicente Sala Martínez, y otro por las tres hermanas, incluida la esposa del acusado, María Fuensanta 'Fany'. Su abogado ha desmentido que Miguel López tuviera un poder de influencia decisivo sobre la marcha de las empresas familiares y ha comentado que en casi 30 años de convivencia y de comer casi a diario, las acusaciones se han acogido a una sola ocasión en la que, en la sobremesa, "se levantó y se fue".
"Un día le gritó, y está mal gritar a la suegra pero no me parece relevante", ha continuado el abogado, quien ha reiterado que lo único que hay contra López son "hipótesis" que no llegan a la categoría de indicios aunque la fiscalía y la acusación las consideren pruebas. Ha defendido que el acusado se haya acogido a su derecho de no declarar para evitar "confundir" y que las acusaciones le hagan "un lío", ya que cree que estas partes "no quieren saber la verdad" sino condenarle.
Por su parte, el fiscal, José Llor, ha pedido la condena de López por ejecutar un crimen "horrendo" motivado por cuestiones "de poder y de dinero", y ha defendido la validez de las "las pruebas no directas sino de indicios" que concluyen que el acusado, "que había vivido a la sombra de la víctima y su marido hasta el punto de que le habían dado trabajo", ha sido el autor material de los disparos.
El fiscal cree que Miguel López cometió el crimen pese a que la familia "tenía suficiente dinero, mucho más de lo que la mayoría de los españoles podemos disfrutar", y ha lamentado especialmente que el acusado se haya acogido a su derecho a no declarar durante el juicio pese a que haya "indicios fuertes".
El abogado de la acusación que ejerce el hijo primogénito (Vicente Sala Martínez), Francisco Ruiz Marco, ha afirmado que fue López "en el único sitio donde el acusado tenía coartada por ser su lugar de trabajo" y ha recordado que los testigos han explicado que un par de semanas antes López gritó a la víctima por los problemas en los negocios y que, además, era la persona del otro bando familiar "con soluciones para todo". "Y decidió solucionarlo", ha añadido.
María del Carmen Martínez falleció ahogada por su propia sangre tras recibir dos disparos poco antes de las 19 horas del 9 de diciembre de 2016 en el concesionario Novocar, de su propiedad y regentado por López, casado con su hija más pequeña, María Fuensanta 'Fany'.
text:
The defense asks for his acquittal
The accused for the crime of the CAM avoids the last word in the trial
06 Nov 2019, 20:15 by The Information

Miguel López has avoided taking advantage of his right to the last word. His defense has requested his acquittal for lack of "direct" evidence

The son-in-law and the only one accused of the shooting crime of the widow of the former president of Caja Mediterráneo (CAM) Vicente Sala, Miguel López, has avoided taking advantage of his right to the last word at the end of the trial in which his defense has requested his acquittal by lack of "direct" evidence. The members of the jury have been summoned this Thursday at 11 am to receive from the magistrate presiding over the trial, Francisca Bru, the questions that will be part of the 'object of the verdict' to, within a period of 48 hours extendable twice, determine if Lopez is guilty or not guilty.
There will be guilt with the possibility of up to 24 years in jail if at least seven of the nine members of the jury so decide and he will be exempted from charges if he has five votes, according to the Law of the Jury. "Nothing, thank you very much," Lopez replied when asked by the magistrate if he wanted to make use of his right to the last word before the verdict, so the only defendant has finished the trial without making any statement, not even his lawyer, Javier Sánchez-Vera.
This has happened at the end of a marathon session of almost eight hours in which the accusations of the prosecutor and the individual and his defense have presented their final conclusions at the seventeenth and final session before the six women and three men of the popular jury of the Provincial Court of Alicante.



Previously and for two and a half hours, his lawyer has tried to dismantle the theses of the accusations, with the argument that there is no direct evidence or even evidence against his defendant but that in the last weeks a "wrong" police investigation has been demonstrated . Sánchez-Vera has affirmed that "when you mislead the investigation from the beginning, nothing can go well" and added that his defendant, Miguel López, was "one of those who best got along with María del Carmen (Martínez), even if it says contrary".
He has insisted that the police investigation has not been "correct" because he has "replaced the scientific evidence with assumptions", which leads to "very clear judicial errors" in case his defendant was found guilty.
During the trial, the family disputes over the control of the companies, valued at about 120 million euros, which resulted in two sides, one formed by the victim and his firstborn son (and private accusation), Vicente Sala Martínez, were reflected. and another for the three sisters, including the wife of the accused, María Fuensanta 'Fany'. His lawyer has denied that Miguel López had a decisive influence on the progress of family businesses and commented that in almost 30 years of living together and eating almost daily, the accusations have taken up only one occasion in which, on the desktop, "got up and left."
"One day he shouted at her, and it is wrong to shout at the mother-in-law but it does not seem relevant to me," continued the lawyer, who reiterated that the only thing against Lopez is "hypotheses" that do not reach the category of evidence although the prosecution and the accusation consider them evidence. He has argued that the accused has accepted his right not to testify to avoid "confusing" and that the accusations make him "a mess", since he believes that these parties "do not want to know the truth" but to condemn him.
For his part, the prosecutor, José Llor, has asked for López's conviction for executing a "horrendous" crime motivated by "power and money" issues, and has defended the validity of "not direct evidence but evidence" They conclude that the defendant, "who had lived in the shadow of the victim and her husband to the point that they had given him work," has been the material author of the shooting.
The prosecutor believes that Miguel López committed the crime despite the fact that the family "had enough money, much more than most Spaniards can enjoy," and has especially regretted that the accused has accepted his right not to testify during the trial even though there are "strong clues".
The lawyer of the accusation exercised by the eldest son (Vicente Sala Martínez), Francisco Ruiz Marco, has affirmed that López was "in the only place where the defendant had an alibi for being his place of work" and recalled that the witnesses have explained that a couple of weeks before López shouted at the victim about the problems in business and that, in addition, he was the person on the other side of the family "with solutions for everything." "And he decided to fix it," he added.
María del Carmen Martínez died drowned by her own blood after receiving two shots shortly before 19 hours on December 9, 2016 at Novocar dealership, owned and run by López, married to her youngest daughter, María Fuensanta 'Fany '.
